text: Daisy Ena Crossley after marriage Daisy Popple (9 June 1906 - 1989)England & Wales, Civil Registration Death Index, 1837â€“2007 was a British racewalker during the 1920s, the early era of women's athletics. She was multiple times world record holder and gold medalist at the second Women's World Games in 1926. ==Biography== ===Career=== On 19 June 1926, she became British national champion in the 880 yards track walk at Stamford Bridge in London. Her time of 4:06.0 was a world record. On 14 July 1926, she improved the 1000 metres world record record during competitions in Paris. In August 1926, initially selected as a reserve, Crossley represented Great Britain at the 1926 Women's World Games in Gothenburg. She won the gold medal in the 1000 m walk beating French Albertine Regel. Crossley won the event in a new world record time of 5:10.0, three seconds faster than the former world record. Her 880 yards time was also a world record with 4:03.0+. As a celebration for winning the event and breaking a world record, Crossley was carried on the shoulders of teammates throughout Gothenburg. ===Personal life=== Crossley was born on 9 June 1906 In 1942 she lived in Fulham, London County. She married in August 1942. title: Daisy Crossley
